elements.content: Five polynuclear complexes of d10 metals with 2-mercaptobenzimidazole (HMBD) or 2-mercaptobenzothiazole (HMBT), namely, [N(CH2CH3)4][Cu3(MBD)2] (1), [N(CH3)(CH2CH3)3]2[Cu6(MBD)6]Cl2 (2), [Ag6(MBT)6] (3), [Zn4(μ4-O)(MBD)6]·3CH3OH (4), and [Zn4(μ4-O)(MBT)6] (5), have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions. The photoluminescence properties of complexes 1−5 have been studied, and three primary colors, red, green, and blue were observed from these complexes.

elements.content: The construction of metal−organic complexes as luminescent materials is one of the most active areas of chemical research due to their applications in the fields of lighting, lasers, sensors, and switches. Among the large number of reported works about the luminescent complexes, the noble and rare earth metals, which are often rather expensive and environmentally problematic, are wildly utilized. In recent years, there has been a growing interest in luminescent complexes based on d10 metals beyond the platinum group, such as copper(I), silver(I), gold(I), and zinc(II), cadmium(II), which are less traditional but much more abundant and cheaper. Thanks to the versatility of their luminescent levels, which can be ligand centered, charge transfer, or, in the case of polynuclear compounds, even metal-centered, many d10 metal compounds with attractive luminescence properties and potentials as new luminescent materials have been synthesized. However, as the synthesis of desired luminescent materials is still a challenge, the method of appropriately incorporating conjugated organic ligands and anionic components into a coordination cluster or polymeric system is undoubtedly an efficient way to adjust luminescent properties, such as fluorescent excitation/emission wavelength, intensity, and lifetime.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The construction of metal-organic complexes as luminescent materials is one of the most active areas of chemical research due to their applications in the fields of lighting, lasers, sensors, and switches. Among the large number of reported works about the luminescent complexes, the noble and rare earth metals, which are often rather expensive and environmentally problematic, are wildly utilized. In recent years, there has been a growing interest in luminescent complexes based on d10 metals beyond the platinum group, such as copper(I), silver(I), gold(I), and zinc(II), cadmium(II), which are less traditional but much more abundant and cheaper. Thanks to the versatility of their luminescent levels, which can be ligand centered, charge transfer, or, in the case of polynuclear compounds, even metal-centered, many d10 metal compounds with attractive luminescence properties and potentials as new luminescent materials have been synthesized. However, as the synthesis of desired luminescent materials is still a challenge, the method of appropriately incorporating conjugated organic ligands and anionic components into a coordination cluster or polymeric system is undoubtedly an efficient way to adjust luminescent properties, such as fluorescent excitation/emission wavelength, intensity, and lifetime.

elements.content: On the other hand, sulfur-containing ligands, especially thiolates, are frequently applied as bridging ligands in the design of transition-metal luminescent materials. The incorporation of thiolate-S as a bridge between adjacent transition-metal sites in coordination complexes is highly desirable in terms of luminescent behavior because the orbital energies are well matched for S and there will be large delocalization of the spin electron density toward the bridging atom. In this work, we report five polynuclear complexes of d10 metals with 2-mercaptobenzoazoles, 2-mercaptobenzimidazole (HMBD), and 2-mercaptobenzothiazole (HMBT) as ligands. These ligands are chosen because of their structurally rigid backbone, their aromatic delocalized electron system, and their relatively large bond angle of ∠S−C−N, thus resulting in a large span distances between the coordination donors, as compared to many 1,1- and 1,2-dithiolate as well as 2-pyridylthiolato derivative ligands. The unique structure of 2-mercaptobenzoazoles and their aromatic properties are expected to generate new d10 metal complexes with surprising structural and spectroscopic features. Five complexes with d10 metals, namely, [N(CH2CH3)4][Cu3(MBD)2] (1), [N(CH3)(CH2CH3)3]2[Cu6(MBD)6]Cl2 (2), [Ag6(MBT)6] (3), [Zn4(μ4-O)(MBD)6]·3CH3OH (4), and [Zn4(μ4-O)(MBT)6] (5) were synthesized under solvothermal conditions and structurally characterized.

These ligands are chosen because of their structurally rigid backbone, their aromatic delocalized electron system, and their relatively large bond angle of ∠S-C-N, thus resulting in a large span distances between the coordination donors, as compared to many 1,1- and 1,2-dithiolate as well as 2-pyridylthiolato derivative ligands. The unique structure of 2-mercaptobenzoazoles and their aromatic properties are expected to generate new d10 metal complexes with surprising structural and spectroscopic features. Five complexes with d10 metals, namely, [N(CH2CH3)4][Cu3(MBD)2] (1), [N(CH3)(CH2CH3)3]2[Cu6(MBD)6]Cl2 (2), [Ag6(MBT)6] (3), [Zn4(μ4-O)(MBD)6]⋅3CH3OH (4), and [Zn4(μ4-O)(MBT)6] (5) were synthesized under solvothermal conditions and structurally characterized.

elements.content: Commercially available reagents were used as received. All syntheses were carried out in 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr autoclaves under autogenous pressure. The elemental analyses were performed on an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded on a PECO (U.S.A.) SpectrumOne spectrophotometer with KBr pellets. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer. The fluorescence spectra were measured on polycrystalline or powder samples at room temperature using a HORIBA Jobin-Yvon FluoroMax-4 spectrometer. The phase purity and crystallinity of each product were checked by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). A step size of 0.05° and counting time of 1.2 s/step were applied in a 2θ range of 5.00−55.00°. The observed and simulated powder XRD patterns of all compounds are displayed in .
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

Commercially available reagents were used as received. All syntheses were carried out in 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr autoclaves under autogenous pressure. The elemental analyses were performed on an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded on a PECO (U.S.A.) SpectrumOne spectrophotometer with KBr pellets. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer. The fluorescence spectra were measured on polycrystalline or powder samples at room temperature using a HORIBA Jobin-Yvon FluoroMax-4 spectrometer. The phase purity and crystallinity of each product were checked by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). A step size of 0.05° and counting time of 1.2 s/step were applied in a 2θ range of 5.00-55.00°. The observed and simulated powder XRD patterns of all compounds are displayed in .

elements.content: A mixture of CuCl (0.050 g, 0.50 mmol), HMBD (0.075 g, 0.50 mmol), and triethylamine (3.0 mL, 0.021 mol) in acetonitrile (10 mL) was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor and heated for 5 days at 160 °C. After cooling of the sample within 1 day, brown crystals of 1 were obtained in 60% yield (0.062 g, base on Cu). Anal. Calc. (%) for: H 4.57; C 42.81; N 11.35. Found: H 4.37; C 42.82; N 11.37. elements.content: Suitable single crystals of 1−4 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Structural data were collected with Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Ǻ) at 293 K. Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the SADABS program. Structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. Crystal data and refinement of 1−4 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S1, . CCDC 743262, 743263, 720537, 743264 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Suitable single crystals of 1-4 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Structural data were collected with Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Ǻ) at 293 K. Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the SADABS program. Structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. Crystal data and refinement of 1-4 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S1, . CCDC 743262, 743263, 720537, 743264 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

The five d10 metal thiolate complexes reported here were simply synthesized under solvothermal reaction conditions. Complexes 1 and 2 were controlled by the amount of triethylamine. Increasing the amount of triethylamine facilitates the formation of complex 1 as a result of further deprotonation of the MBD ligands. The starting reagent was converted into the MBT ligand via the in situ cleavage of the S−S bond or the C−S(sp) bond (Scheme ) when complexes 3 and 5 were prepared under solvothermal reaction conditions similar to those found in other literature reports. Although S−S bond cleavage is easy under solvothermal conditions, C−S bond cleavage is much less frequent and has only been recently reported. Complex 5 had been reported, but the result is suspicious because zinc was absent in the staring materials. The structure of 5 is a tetranuclear cluster of zinc. All details of the structure had already been discussed, and in this paper we just focus on the luminescent property of complex 5. In addition, when 3-(2-benzothiazolythio)-propionic acid reacted with CuCl2·2H2O in methanol and ammonia, red crystals which were reported by other group were obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and General Characterization

The five d10 metal thiolate complexes reported here were simply synthesized under solvothermal reaction conditions. Complexes 1 and 2 were controlled by the amount of triethylamine. Increasing the amount of triethylamine facilitates the formation of complex 1 as a result of further deprotonation of the MBD ligands. The starting reagent was converted into the MBT ligand via the in situ cleavage of the S-S bond or the C-S(sp) bond (Scheme ) when complexes 3 and 5 were prepared under solvothermal reaction conditions similar to those found in other literature reports. Although S-S bond cleavage is easy under solvothermal conditions, C-S bond cleavage is much less frequent and has only been recently reported. Complex 5 had been reported, but the result is suspicious because zinc was absent in the staring materials. The structure of 5 is a tetranuclear cluster of zinc. All details of the structure had already been discussed, and in this paper we just focus on the luminescent property of complex 5. In addition, when 3-(2-benzothiazolythio)-propionic acid reacted with CuCl2⋅2H2O in methanol and ammonia, red crystals which were reported by other group were obtained.

The structure of compound 1 is a two-dimensional layer network constructed with a tetranuclear cluster of copper. It consists of two Cu(I) ions, one 2-MBD ligand, and two quarter tetraethyl ammonium ions in the crystallographically asymmetric independent unit (Figure a). The ammonium cations may be generated from the in situ reaction of triethylamine under the solvothermal conditions. However, the reaction mechanism is unclear and will be further investigated. The two crystallographically independent copper centers have different coordination environments. Cu1 is two coordinated to two nitrogen atoms from two different ligands (Cu1−N1 = 1.846(4) Ǻ). Cu2 is three-coordinated in a distorted trigonal planar coordination geometry, which is completed by two sulfur atoms and one nitrogen from three MBD ligands (Cu2−S1 = 2.2344(15) Ǻ, Cu2−S1A = 2.3772(18) Ǻ, Cu2−N2A = 1.963(5) Ǻ). The connectivity between the Cu2 and the MBD ligands gives rise to a tetrahedral Cu4 cluster (Figure b). The Cu4 tetrahedron is slightly flattened with Cu−Cu distances of 2.7751(6) Ǻ (Cu2−Cu2a, Cu2a−Cu2b, Cu2b−Cu2c, Cu2−Cu2c) and 2.8136(6) Ǻ (Cu2−Cu2b, Cu2c−Cu2a). The bond angle around Cu1 is 179.6°, while the bond angles around Cu2 vary from 100.86° to 138.81°. Each MBD ligand adopts μ3-bridging coordination mode, which bridges between the tetrameric copper aggregate through its thionato-S atom (S1) and nitrogen atom (N2) and Cu1 through its nitrogen atom (N1) to form a 2D layer network in the ab plane (Figure c).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of Complexes

[N(CH2CH3)4][Cu3(MBD)2] (1)

The structure of compound 1 is a two-dimensional layer network constructed with a tetranuclear cluster of copper. It consists of two Cu(I) ions, one 2-MBD ligand, and two quarter tetraethyl ammonium ions in the crystallographically asymmetric independent unit (Figure a). The ammonium cations may be generated from the in situ reaction of triethylamine under the solvothermal conditions. However, the reaction mechanism is unclear and will be further investigated. The two crystallographically independent copper centers have different coordination environments. Cu1 is two coordinated to two nitrogen atoms from two different ligands (Cu1-N1 = 1.846(4) Ǻ). Cu2 is three-coordinated in a distorted trigonal planar coordination geometry, which is completed by two sulfur atoms and one nitrogen from three MBD ligands (Cu2-S1 = 2.2344(15) Ǻ, Cu2-S1A = 2.3772(18) Ǻ, Cu2-N2A = 1.963(5) Ǻ). The connectivity between the Cu2 and the MBD ligands gives rise to a tetrahedral Cu4 cluster (Figure b). The Cu4 tetrahedron is slightly flattened with Cu-Cu distances of 2.7751(6) Ǻ (Cu2-Cu2a, Cu2a-Cu2b, Cu2b-Cu2c, Cu2-Cu2c) and 2.8136(6) Ǻ (Cu2-Cu2b, Cu2c-Cu2a). The bond angle around Cu1 is 179.6°, while the bond angles around Cu2 vary from 100.86° to 138.81°. Each MBD ligand adopts μ3-bridging coordination mode, which bridges between the tetrameric copper aggregate through its thionato-S atom (S1) and nitrogen atom (N2) and Cu1 through its nitrogen atom (N1) to form a 2D layer network in the ab plane (Figure c).

elements.content: Complex 2 is a hexanuclear cluster of Cu(I), containing six Cu atoms, six MBD ligands, and two couples of Cl− and MeNEt3 + as dissociative counterions. The ammonium cations may be generated from the in situ reaction between acetonitrile and triethylamine under solvothermal conditions. However, the reaction mechanism is unclear and will be further investigated. The structure of 2 is shown in Figure a. The center of the cluster can be described as 12-membered Cu6S6 rings with three ligands above and below the rings, respectively. The six copper atoms in this cluster are significantly formed in a chair configuration with individual Cu···Cu distances of 2.8363(11) Ǻ. It is to be noted that this configuration is seldom reported among the hexanuclear cluster of copper. Each copper center is three-coordinated in a distorted trigonal planar coordination geometry, which is completed by two sulfur atoms and one nitrogen from three MBD ligands (Cu1−S1 = 2.2498(18) Ǻ, Cu1−S1A = 2.2752(18) Ǻ, Cu1−N1A = 1.982(5) Ǻ). Each ligand coordinated to three copper atoms using a μ2-bridging thiolate sulfur atom and a monodentate nitrogen atom.
elements.clean_text:
[N(CH3)(CH2CH3)3]2[Cu6(MBD)6]Cl2 (2)

Complex 2 is a hexanuclear cluster of Cu(I), containing six Cu atoms, six MBD ligands, and two couples of Cl- and MeNEt3 + as dissociative counterions. The ammonium cations may be generated from the in situ reaction between acetonitrile and triethylamine under solvothermal conditions. However, the reaction mechanism is unclear and will be further investigated. The structure of 2 is shown in Figure a. The center of the cluster can be described as 12-membered Cu6S6 rings with three ligands above and below the rings, respectively. The six copper atoms in this cluster are significantly formed in a chair configuration with individual Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances of 2.8363(11) Ǻ. It is to be noted that this configuration is seldom reported among the hexanuclear cluster of copper. Each copper center is three-coordinated in a distorted trigonal planar coordination geometry, which is completed by two sulfur atoms and one nitrogen from three MBD ligands (Cu1-S1 = 2.2498(18) Ǻ, Cu1-S1A = 2.2752(18) Ǻ, Cu1-N1A = 1.982(5) Ǻ). Each ligand coordinated to three copper atoms using a μ2-bridging thiolate sulfur atom and a monodentate nitrogen atom.

elements.content: The molecule is neutral and composed of six Ag(I) atoms bridged by six tridentate MBT monoanions (Figure ). It crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with only half of the molecules being independent crystallographically. Each of the metal centers is three-coordinated by one nitrogen atom and two thiolate sulfur atoms from three MBT ligands, forming a distorted trigonal {MNS2} geometry. Meanwhile, each MTB ligand serves as a tridentate ligand to connect three metal atoms by using its thiolate sulfur atom as a μ2 linker to connect two metal atoms, and its nitrogen atoms to coordinate the third metal atom. The six silver atoms formed a distorted octahedron with Ag···Ag distances in the range of 3.103 (2) to 3.188(2) Ǻ, which are larger than in bulky metals (2.88 Ǻ) and are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals separations (van der Waals radii for Ag, 1.70 Ǻ).

[Ag6(MBT)6] (3)

The molecule is neutral and composed of six Ag(I) atoms bridged by six tridentate MBT monoanions (Figure ). It crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with only half of the molecules being independent crystallographically. Each of the metal centers is three-coordinated by one nitrogen atom and two thiolate sulfur atoms from three MBT ligands, forming a distorted trigonal {MNS2} geometry. Meanwhile, each MTB ligand serves as a tridentate ligand to connect three metal atoms by using its thiolate sulfur atom as a μ2 linker to connect two metal atoms, and its nitrogen atoms to coordinate the third metal atom. The six silver atoms formed a distorted octahedron with Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances in the range of 3.103 (2) to 3.188(2) Ǻ, which are larger than in bulky metals (2.88 Ǻ) and are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals separations (van der Waals radii for Ag, 1.70 Ǻ).

elements.content: The structure of 4 contains discrete molecules having a crystallographically imposed symmetry with four molecules of the complex and 12 molecules of solvating methanol in the unit cell. The complex contains a central oxygen atom coordinated to four zinc atoms which forms a disordered tetrahedron (with angles of 58.93(2)° for Zn4−Zn1−Zn3 and 61.8(2)° for Zn4−Zn3−Zn1), bridged by six ligands along the edges of the tetrahedron, as shown in Figure a. The distances between zinc atoms are in the range of 3.1865(6)−3.25625(7) Ǻ. Each zinc atom is tetrahedral coordination. The Zn1 atom is bound to the oxygen atom and to three MBD ligands (to two via nitrogen atoms and to one via the sulfur atom). The Zn2 atom is tetra-coordinated to the oxygen atom and to three nitrogen atoms from three different bridging ligands. The Zn3 atom is tetra-coordinated to the oxygen atom and to three sulfur atoms from three different bridging ligands. The Zn4 atom is bound to the oxygen atom and to three MBD ligands (to one via nitrogen atom and to two via the sulfur atoms).

[Zn4(μ4-O)(MBD)6]⋅3CH3OH (4)

The structure of 4 contains discrete molecules having a crystallographically imposed symmetry with four molecules of the complex and 12 molecules of solvating methanol in the unit cell. The complex contains a central oxygen atom coordinated to four zinc atoms which forms a disordered tetrahedron (with angles of 58.93(2)° for Zn4-Zn1-Zn3 and 61.8(2)° for Zn4-Zn3-Zn1), bridged by six ligands along the edges of the tetrahedron, as shown in Figure a. The distances between zinc atoms are in the range of 3.1865(6)-3.25625(7) Ǻ. Each zinc atom is tetrahedral coordination. The Zn1 atom is bound to the oxygen atom and to three MBD ligands (to two via nitrogen atoms and to one via the sulfur atom). The Zn2 atom is tetra-coordinated to the oxygen atom and to three nitrogen atoms from three different bridging ligands. The Zn3 atom is tetra-coordinated to the oxygen atom and to three sulfur atoms from three different bridging ligands. The Zn4 atom is bound to the oxygen atom and to three MBD ligands (to one via nitrogen atom and to two via the sulfur atoms).

elements.content: In addition, π−π stacking and hydrogen bonding interaction play an important role in forming this structure. The N2 and N5 atoms of the MBD ligands are hydrogen-bonded to the oxygen atoms of the solvating methanol molecules (N2···H2A···O3M: 3.0959 Ǻ; N5···H5A···O1M: 2.7752 Ǻ), bridging two clusters together into a dimer. Meanwhile, the dimer is stabilized by strong π−π interactions between two benzene rings from two MBT ligands of two neighboring clusters (the plane-to-plane distance of this π−π stacking is 3.509 Ǻ), as shown in Figure b. Furthermore, the N3 atom of the MBD ligand is hydrogen-bonded to the S8 atom from the other cluster (N3···H3A···S8: 3.4185 Ǻ), and link the dimers into a 1D supramolecular chain (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: In addition, π-π stacking and hydrogen bonding interaction play an important role in forming this structure. The N2 and N5 atoms of the MBD ligands are hydrogen-bonded to the oxygen atoms of the solvating methanol molecules (N2⋅⋅⋅H2A⋅⋅⋅O3M: 3.0959 Ǻ; N5⋅⋅⋅H5A⋅⋅⋅O1M: 2.7752 Ǻ), bridging two clusters together into a dimer. Meanwhile, the dimer is stabilized by strong π-π interactions between two benzene rings from two MBT ligands of two neighboring clusters (the plane-to-plane distance of this π-π stacking is 3.509 Ǻ), as shown in Figure b. Furthermore, the N3 atom of the MBD ligand is hydrogen-bonded to the S8 atom from the other cluster (N3⋅⋅⋅H3A⋅⋅⋅S8: 3.4185 Ǻ), and link the dimers into a 1D supramolecular chain (Figure b).

Photoluminescent Properties

In this work, photoluminescence properties of complexes 1-5 have been explored at room temperature in the solid states. Their emission spectra are shown in Figure  and Figure S3, . Their photoluminescent data in the solid state were summarized in Table S2, .

elements.content: Emission spectrum of 1 and 3−5 in solid state at room temperature ((inset: luminescence of complex 1 (top), 3 (middle), and 4 (bottom) under ultraviolet light illumination at room temperature).
elements.clean_text: 5  Emission spectrum of 1 and 3-5 in solid state at room temperature ((inset: luminescence of complex 1 (top), 3 (middle), and 4 (bottom) under ultraviolet light illumination at room temperature).

elements.content: Complex 1 displayed an intense green emission band with a peak maximum at 518 nm (excitation at 360 nm) under UV light. The emissions are suggested to be phosphorescence based on their microsecond-order decay lifetime (Table S2, ). According to the previous reports about the polynuclear Cu(I)-thiolate clusters, the emission is tentatively assigned as originating from the triplet states of metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) character mixed with a cluster-centered (d-s/d-p) CuI state. On the other hand, complex 2 is not photoluminescent. That may be due to the longer metal−metal distances than those in compound 1. It is known that short metal−metal internuclear distances and consequently significant interactions between the metal centers can greatly enhance the luminescent properties of polynuclear d10 metal complexes.

elements.content: Complex 3 displayed a bright red emission under UV light and the emission spectrum (upon excitation at 450 nm) shows a red emission band with peak maximum 641 nm. Similar to 1, we assume that the red emission of 3 originates from a metal-centered triplet state modified by Ag−Ag interactions with Ag6 clusters.

elements.content: The two tetranuclear zinc(II) compounds, 4 and 5, exhibit intense blue emissions with a peak maximum at 402 nm and 422 nm, respectively. On the basis of experimental and theoretical results for the μ 4 -oxo-bridged tetranuclear Zn(II) compounds, these blue emissions may be assigned to the LMCT transition of pπ (O2−, L) → 4sσ (M).

elements.content: In this study, the thermal stabilities of all five compounds were analyzed on crystalline samples by TGA/differential thermal analyis (DTA) from 30 to 900 °C at rate of 10 °C min−1, under nitrogen atmospheres with a flowing rate of 20 mL min−1. TGA profiles for complexes 1−5 are shown in Figure S2, . Complex 1 exhibits high thermal stability. The sample starts to collapse at 310 °C; the 53.7% mass loss between 310 and 900 °C should correspond to the loss of the amine cations and organic ligands benzimidazole (calcd 58.7%). Complex 2 starts to collapse at 285 °C; the 63.4% mass loss occurring when the sample is heated up to 700 °C should correspond to the loss of the counterions and organic ligands benzimidazole (calcd 63.6%). Complex 3 exhibits high thermal stability; it was stable up to 335 °C, and then a rapid mass loss (60.5%) occurs. It is in good agreement with the calculated value (60.6%) for the decomposition of organic ligands. As for complex 4, there is a little weight loss (7.0%) between 81 and 180 °C, which corresponds to the release of the molecules of solvating methanol (calcd 7.5%). And then a rapid mass loss (71.7%) occurring from 365 °C corresponds to the removal of the residual organic species (calcd 72.3%). Complex 5 starts to collapse at 325 °C, and then a two-step collapse occurs. Heating above 700 °C results in a complete collapse of 5 and is accompanied by a rapid mass change as the organic component burns off.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

In this study, the thermal stabilities of all five compounds were analyzed on crystalline samples by TGA/differential thermal analyis (DTA) from 30 to 900 °C at rate of 10 °C min-1, under nitrogen atmospheres with a flowing rate of 20 mL min-1. TGA profiles for complexes 1-5 are shown in Figure S2, . Complex 1 exhibits high thermal stability. The sample starts to collapse at 310 °C; the 53.7% mass loss between 310 and 900 °C should correspond to the loss of the amine cations and organic ligands benzimidazole (calcd 58.7%). Complex 2 starts to collapse at 285 °C; the 63.4% mass loss occurring when the sample is heated up to 700 °C should correspond to the loss of the counterions and organic ligands benzimidazole (calcd 63.6%). Complex 3 exhibits high thermal stability; it was stable up to 335 °C, and then a rapid mass loss (60.5%) occurs. It is in good agreement with the calculated value (60.6%) for the decomposition of organic ligands. As for complex 4, there is a little weight loss (7.0%) between 81 and 180 °C, which corresponds to the release of the molecules of solvating methanol (calcd 7.5%). And then a rapid mass loss (71.7%) occurring from 365 °C corresponds to the removal of the residual organic species (calcd 72.3%). Complex 5 starts to collapse at 325 °C, and then a two-step collapse occurs. Heating above 700 °C results in a complete collapse of 5 and is accompanied by a rapid mass change as the organic component burns off.

elements.content: In summary, five new polynuclear complexes of d10 metals have been synthesized via the solvothermal method, and structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction analysis. Complex 3 and 5 were generated in situ through the cleavage of S−S or S−C(sp2) bonds. Except for 2, all the complexes exhibit strong fluorescence in the solid state with three primary colors, red, green and blue. On the basis of this work, further synthesis and luminescent property studies of d10 metals with other thiolate ligands are under way in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, five new polynuclear complexes of d10 metals have been synthesized via the solvothermal method, and structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction analysis. Complex 3 and 5 were generated in situ through the cleavage of S-S or S-C(sp2) bonds. Except for 2, all the complexes exhibit strong fluorescence in the solid state with three primary colors, red, green and blue. On the basis of this work, further synthesis and luminescent property studies of d10 metals with other thiolate ligands are under way in our laboratory.

A mixture of CuCl (0.050 g, 0.50 mmol), HMBD (0.075 g, 0.50 mmol), and triethylamine (3.0 mL, 0.021 mol) in acetonitrile (10 mL) was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor and heated for 5 days at 160 °C. After cooling of the sample within 1 day, brown crystals of 1 were obtained in 60% yield (0.062 g, base on Cu). Anal. Calc. (%) for: H 4.57; C 42.81; N 11.35. Found: H 4.37; C 42.82; N 11.37. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3853(w), 3745(w), 3649(w), 1454(m), 1370(m), 1357(m), 1305(s), 1219(m), 1192(m), 1102(w), 1002(w), 742(m), 732(m).

Synthesis of [N(CH<sub>3</sub>)(CH<sub>2</sub>CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>]<sub>2</sub>[Cu<sub>6</sub>(MBD)<sub>6</sub>]Cl<sub>2</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of CuCl (0.050 g, 0.50 mmol) and HMBD (0.075 g, 0.50 mmol) in 10 mL of acetonitrile and 1.0 mL of triethylamine was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor and heated for 5 days at 160 °C, and cooling to room temperature within 1 day, yellow crystals of 2 were obtained in 42% yield (0.056 g, based on Cu). Anal. Calc. (%) for: H 4.21; C 42.58; N 12.41. Found: H 4.00; C 42.55; N 12.36. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3445(w), 3067(s), 3031(s), 1424(s), 1385(s), 1350(m), 1294(w), 1274(m), 1228(w), 1193(w), 1007(w), 988(w), 755(m).

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>6</sub>(MBT)<sub>6</sub>] (<bold>3</bold>)

A mixture of Ag(CH3COO) (0.084 g, 0.50 mmol) and 3-(2-benzothiazolythio)-propionic acid (0.11 g, 0.50 mmol) in 10 mL of acetonitrile was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor and heated for 4 days at 150 °C. After cooling of the sample within 2 days, yellow crystals of 3 were obtained in 31% yield (0.042 g, based on Ag). Anal. Calc. (%) for: H 1.47; C 30.67; N 5.11; Found: H 1.33; C 30.70; N 5.29. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3429(w), 3060(w), 1449(m), 1404(s), 1310(m), 1277(w), 1243(m), 1126(w), 1077(m), 1002(s), 748(s), 720(m), 691(w).

Synthesis of [Zn<sub>4</sub>(μ<sub>4</sub>-O)(MBD)<sub>6</sub>]·3CH<sub>3</sub>OH (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.055 g, 0.25 mmol) and HMBD (0.056 g, 0.37 mmol) in 5 mL of water and 5 mL of methanol was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor and heated for 3 days at 120 °C, and cooling to room temperature within 2 days, colorless crystals of 4 were obtained in 83% yield (0.066 g, based on Zn). Anal. Calc. (%) for: H 3.34; C 42.60; N 13.25. Found: H 3.24; C 42.30; N 13.25. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3394(m), 3292(w), 1490(w), 1417(s), 1380(s), 1348(m), 1296(m), 1273(m), 1223(m), 1168(w), 10168(w), 1000(m), 740(s), 601(w), 490(m).

Synthesis of [Zn<sub>4</sub>(μ<sub>4</sub>-O)(MBT)<sub>6</sub>] (<bold>5</bold>)

Method 1. A mixture of Zn (0.025 g, 0.33 mmol) and 2, 2′-dithiobis(benzothiazole) (0.083 g, 0.25 mmol) in 10 mL of alcohol was sealed in a 20-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor and heated for 5 days at 150 °C. After cooling of the sample within 1 day, colorless crystals of 5 were obtained in 36% yield (0.038 g, base on Zn). Method 2. A mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.11 g, 0.50 mmol) and 2,2′-dithiobis(benzothiazole) (0.056 g, 0.37 mmol) in 10 mL of alcohol was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor and heated for 3 days at 120 °C. cln_elements.content: In this study, the thermal stabilities of all five compounds were analyzed on crystalline samples by TGA/differential thermal analyis (DTA) from 30 to 900 °C at rate of 10 °C min−1, under nitrogen atmospheres with a flowing rate of 20 mL min−1. TGA profiles for complexes 1−5 are shown in Figure S2, . Complex 1 exhibits high thermal stability. The sample starts to collapse at 310 °C; the 53.7% mass loss between 310 and 900 °C should correspond to the loss of the amine cations and organic ligands benzimidazole (calcd 58.7%). Complex 2 starts to collapse at 285 °C; the 63.4% mass loss occurring when the sample is heated up to 700 °C should correspond to the loss of the counterions and organic ligands benzimidazole (calcd 63.6%). Complex 3 exhibits high thermal stability; it was stable up to 335 °C, and then a rapid mass loss (60.5%) occurs. It is in good agreement with the calculated value (60.6%) for the decomposition of organic ligands. As for complex 4, there is a little weight loss (7.0%) between 81 and 180 °C, which corresponds to the release of the molecules of solvating methanol (calcd 7.5%). And then a rapid mass loss (71.7%) occurring from 365 °C corresponds to the removal of the residual organic species (calcd 72.3%). Complex 5 starts to collapse at 325 °C, and then a two-step collapse occurs. Heating above 700 °C results in a complete collapse of 5 and is accompanied by a rapid mass change as the organic component burns off.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

In this study, the thermal stabilities of all five compounds were analyzed on crystalline samples by TGA/differential thermal analyis (DTA) from 30 to 900 °C at rate of 10 °C min-1, under nitrogen atmospheres with a flowing rate of 20 mL min-1. TGA profiles for complexes 1-5 are shown in Figure S2, . Complex 1 exhibits high thermal stability. The sample starts to collapse at 310 °C; the 53.7% mass loss between 310 and 900 °C should correspond to the loss of the amine cations and organic ligands benzimidazole (calcd 58.7%). Complex 2 starts to collapse at 285 °C; the 63.4% mass loss occurring when the sample is heated up to 700 °C should correspond to the loss of the counterions and organic ligands benzimidazole (calcd 63.6%). Complex 3 exhibits high thermal stability; it was stable up to 335 °C, and then a rapid mass loss (60.5%) occurs. It is in good agreement with the calculated value (60.6%) for the decomposition of organic ligands. As for complex 4, there is a little weight loss (7.0%) between 81 and 180 °C, which corresponds to the release of the molecules of solvating methanol (calcd 7.5%). And then a rapid mass loss (71.7%) occurring from 365 °C corresponds to the removal of the residual organic species (calcd 72.3%). Complex 5 starts to collapse at 325 °C, and then a two-step collapse occurs. Heating above 700 °C results in a complete collapse of 5 and is accompanied by a rapid mass change as the organic component burns off.
